newsitem.title: UK: RUGBY UNION-FRENCH PHILOSOPHY DECISIVE, SAYS VILLEPREUX.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-FRENCH PHILOSOPHY DECISIVE, SAYS VILLEPREUX.

text.p: France's extraordinary 23-20 win over England at Twickenham on Saturday was a question of mind over matter, according to French assistant coach Pierre Villepreux.
It may have been two converted tries and a penalty from Christophe Lamaison which transformed a 20-6 deficit, but Villepreux insisted afterwards that France's attitude had been the decisive factor.

"Our philosophy won," said Villepreux, the former international turned coaching guru who has only recently been welcomed back into the French set-up. "We played the rugby I like and we played it well. Mentally, we were superior."
Coach Jean-Claude Skrela agreed his men "looked the fresher team in the second-half" and acknowledged Lamaison's 18 points had transformed that potential into a momentous win.
"We always had confidence in him as a goalkicker. He was a leading character in our win today but the whole team deserves praise."
England coach Jack Rowell, whose future in the role remains uncertain, hinted his side might have been guilty of easing up with victory apparently in sight.
"We were 20-6 up, perhaps we thought the game was over," said Rowell, who described the finale as "the worst 20 minutes of my life".
"Mentally, we slackened off a bit. It was a hard lesson. We won't make the same mistake again."
Rowell, who hinted before the match his business commitments might prevent him accepting a new contract as coach, tried to play down the pre-match reports.
"The situation is made more complex by the game having gone professional," said Rowell, a successful industrialist. "I'm sure the dust will settle and everything will be sorted out."
An RFU spokesman said Rowell had still to be offered a new two-year contract to take charge of England up to the 1999 World Cup.
